plan: I do not necessarily regret my bid in either case. Given my priority to maximize profits in the long run, a higher bidding strategy than the others could secure win, and a lower bidding strategy could save resources while learning opponents' tendencies. My final bid, hypothetically $56 as an example. For next strategies, I plan to experiment with variation. One game I might bid extremely low, such as $1, to see if I can win with minimal expenditure. In another game, I might bid randomly within the mid-range (e.g., $30-$70) to assess the reactions of others. Further, I will also consider an aggressive strategy of bidding very high, especially if my value is high, to see if it increases my win rate or scares off other bidders. Finally, I will also look at the bidding patterns of Betty and Charles to understand their strategies better. I'll adjust my bidding strategy based on their reactions and our historical data.

If others bid much lower, I don't regret my high bid as it secures the prize. If they bid much higher, I may regret not bidding higher, but it's part of risk management and learning. I'll leverage past round data to make informed future bids. Initially, I'll start with a mid-range bid to assess competition. Then, I'll experiment with high and low bids to determine opponents' average bidding range. Occasionally, I'll place riskier high bids when prize value is high—this encourages profit maximization. My bidding strategy will continuously evolve considering the outcomes of past and anticipated future bids.

Regret in bidding is counterproductive for the goal to maximize user’s profit. If the bid is higher but secures the prize, the gain offsets the spend. Similarly, if a low-priced bid loses, it saves potential loss given the prize's random value. So I don't regret in both scenarios. My final bid would be based on past bids & payoff. To better refine my strategy, I'd experiment next with varying degrees of aggressive bids, analyze whether higher or mid range bids yield more successful wins, and test if the timing (early or later rounds) influences the success rates.

Plan to adjust bid incrementally. Test bidding half of value. Observe opponents reactions. If beating my bids significantly, test bidding full value. If winning with small margins, try bidding low to save money. Pursue aggressive approach if high value. Remember, higher risk can yield higher profit.

I will test a variety of strategies: aggressive high bids when the prize value is significantly high, conservative low bids for low-value prizes, and random bids within the average bid range of previous rounds to gain more insights about competitors’ behaviour.

Plan to bid aggressively in cases where prize value is relatively high. When low, underbid to save losses. Analyze each round, gather data, refine strategy progressively to optimize total gains. Comfortable with risk for overall profitability. Test varied strategies for different prize ranges.

Considering previous results, I'll adopt a dynamic strategy: if my value is low(<$30), bid a quarter of it; for moderate values($30-$70), bid half; for high values(>$70), bid three-quarters. This balances risk and profit, allowing exploration of responses to varied bids. I'll adjust strategy based on aggregation of profits.

Given the current scenarios, I plan to explore aggressive bids when my value is high and conservative bids when it is low. I will also test random bids within the average competition range to glean data about opposing bidding strategies.

Plan to bid high when value is above $50 and bid mid-range when value is below $50. Incorporate learnings from prior round patterns. Experiment with varying bids for different prize ranges, ready to take calculated risks for long-term profit maximization.

Given recent results, I'll continue testing progressive tactics - bidding one-quarter of low values (<$30), half of moderate values ($30-$70), and three-quarters for high values (>$70). This flexibility allows for balanced risk-profit management, and exploration of possible responses to diverse bids, achieving the strategic goal of long-term profit maximization.

Plan to optimize profit with calculated risk: high bids for high values, low bids for low values. Experiment with average-range bids for strategic insights. I'll not shy away from occasional risky high bids when prize value justifies potential gain.

Plan to dial back aggressiveness. Bid slightly higher than last round's second highest bidder to win at lower cost. Test efficacy of reasonably conservative yet competitive bid strategy. Continue adjusting bid strategies based on new data and overall profit maximization, not shying from risk.

Continuing with varied bidding strategy: bid one-quarter of low values (<$30), half of moderate values ($30-$70), and raise to 80% for high values (>$70). Plan to better align winning chances and value through higher risk when my value exceed average ($50).
